reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: Netflix sits squarely in the world of streaming media, content licensing deals and rapid subscriber churn—far outside my simple, branded consumer-products comfort zone. If I don’t understand the game, I don’t play. 2. Competitive Moat: I see no durable moat. Disney+, Amazon Prime Video and newcomers are poaching content and customers. Content costs are high and replicable. 3. Management & Capital Allocation: Recent stock issuances dilute existing owners, and there’s no dividend or buyback discipline—hardly the mark of owners thinking long term. 4. Financial Health & Consistency: Yes, operating margins look strong at 66%, but ROE is negative (-2.5%), ROIC is negative and historical consistency is lacking. 5. Valuation: With intrinsic value around $40 and a market price above that, there’s no margin of safety (–77%). I’d rather own a solid business at a fair price. 6. Long-Term Prospects: The content arms race demands heavy spending, the competitive landscape is ruthless and subscriber growth can stall. 7. Opportunity Cost: I’d deploy capital into businesses like Coca-Cola or Apple where pricing power, brand and management quality are clear. In short, this is outside my circle; I’m not interested—bearish on NFLX.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of -2.5%; Conservative debt levels; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

moat_analysis.details: Insufficient data for comprehensive moat analysis

book_value_analysis.details: Moderate book value per share growth

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (3.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (1.5%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
